item.title: Remembering the Thunderbird Hotel and Casino: A Vintage Las Vegas Icon
item.description:
A Southwest Welcome on the Early Strip

The Las Vegas Strip wasn’t always the sprawling behemoth it is today. Back in 1948, it was a fledgling stretch of highway (Highway 91, now the Strip) with just a handful of resorts vying for the attention of visitors. Among them stood the Thunderbird Hotel and Casino, a vibrant addition to the evolving landscape and a symbol of early Vegas ambition.

Opened on September 2, 1948, the Thunderbird wasn’t initially destined to be the Thunderbird. Originally planned as the “Nevada Ambassador,” the name change reflected a shift towards a distinctly Southwestern theme. Developers Marion Hicks (who previously built the El Cortez) and Nevada’s Lieutenant Governor Clifford A. Jones, along with Joe Wells (father of the beloved Dawn Wells), envisioned a resort that would capture the spirit of the region. While the initial budget was set at $1 million, the soaring costs of construction ultimately exceeded $2 million – a significant sum in those days.
